Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: High-Speed Imaging Studies of Fuel-Spray Physics for Low-Temperature and Low-Density Ambient Conditions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Increasingly, engines and power-generation systems are employing spray-based methods to introduce fuel into the combustion chamber. Sprays and spray combustion involve both physical processes (e.g., fuel vaporization, fuel-air mixing) and chemical processes (e.g., ignition, pollutant formation), neither of which are fully understood. In addition, vaporization and mixing set the initial conditions for combustion, and thus directly influence combustion efficiency and emissions. The purpose of this research is to investigate the physical processes involved in fuel sprays, particularly for conditions where fuel is sprayed into relatively low-temperature and low-density surroundings. Such conditions are characteristic of advanced engine combustion strategies, such as early direct-injection, which are increasingly being used to enhance efficiency and lower unwanted emissions. Research will be conducted in a spray chamber designed with extensive optical access, and through which an inert gas will flow continuously during experiments to allow fundamental studies of spray physics in the absence of the complicating effects of combustion. Studies will focus on penetration, dispersion, and turbulence of both the liquid and vapor phases of fuel sprays. These data will be sought using novel high-speed imaging techniques that will be developed as part of this project. The investigator will attempt to develop a technique to obtain both liquid- and vapor-phase information simultaneously using a single high-speed camera. Experimental results could lead to development of improved and more-flexible models that are likely to challenge conventional wisdom about fuel sprays.

This project will have a direct and tangible effect on participation from underrepresented groups by providing support for the research activities and graduate education of an underrepresented student. In addition, the project will benefit undergraduate education in the Mechanical Engineering Department at The University of Alabama, as the investigator will incorporate the subject matter and results of the research into both the lecture and laboratory portions of an existing course in combustion engines. More broadly, the work will contribute to improvement of predictive spray and combustion models, which in turn will contribute to the development of cleaner and more-efficient combustion devices. This research, therefore, has the potential to impact the energy security and energy independence of this nation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this work was to use high-speed imaging methods to explore the physical processes involved in fuel sprays, particularly for the low-temperature and low-density ambient conditions characteristic of low-temperature combustion (LTC) in engines. The primary outcome of this project was the completion of the experimental platform that will be used for current and future fuel-spray research. This platform is a continuous-flow cylindrical vessel with four-sided orthogonal optical access, and is equipped with multiple pressure and temperature sensors to measure and record thermodynamic conditions inside the vessel. In addition to the vessel, it was necessary to set up and optimize a high-speed spray-visualization system. This system consists of a high-speed pulsed LED (light-emitting diode) array, a high-speed camera, and associated electronics for synchronization and data acquisition. A second critical outcome of this project was acquisition of a baseline set of experimental data that verified the functionality and utility of the entire experimental platform. High-speed images of fuel-injection sprays were acquired for n-heptane at two different conditions – (1) room temperature and pressure, to verify that the fuel-injection and spray-visualization systems are working; and (2) 100°C and 100 psi, to verify that the gas-flow and heating systems are working and that the vessel is able to withstand the thermodynamic conditions. All preliminary tests have been successful, experiments have been successful, and the entire system is operational. The final important outcome of this project was a peer-reviewed conference publication. Development of the vessel, as well as the initial baseline experiments, are described in a paper (paper # ASME ICEF2013-19102) that was reviewed and accepted for publication and presentation at the ASME Internal Combustion Engines Division Fall 2013 Technical Conference in Dearborn, MI. In addition, this paper will be substantially upgraded with newer experimental data and results from computational models of vessel strength and gas flow, and the improved paper will be submitted to the ASME Journal of Energy Resources Technology, a peer-reviewed and refereed scientific journal.

This project was expected to have broader impacts in four areas: (1) societal benefits, (2) enhancement of research infrastructure, (3) broadening of participation from underrepresented groups, and (4) dissemination of research to enhance scientific and technological understanding. This project is a starting point for a body of research on fuel sprays that is expected to lead to cleaner and more efficient engines, thus benefiting society as a whole. Research infrastructure has been improved, as this project enabled completion of the experimental platform. There was a direct effect on underrepresented groups, as this project supported a black graduate student and enabled completion of his Master’s thesis. The student will defend his thesis this semester and is expected to graduate in December 2013. Finally, through publication and presentation at the ASME Internal Combustion Engines Division conference, as well as through near-future journal publications, results from this project will be disseminated to the wider combustion community and thus contribute to greater understanding of fuel sprays.
